[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.2 Scope: RMS supports ingredient tracking, dish composition, meal tracking, table assignments, and client management.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.1 Purpose: The Restaurant Management System (RMS) defines requirements for managing meal preparation, inventory, dish composition, reservations, and waiter assignments.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.4 Product Functions: RMS manages inventory, dish preparation, table assignments, meals, and customer records.

[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.1 System Interfaces: RMS integrates with inventory, restaurant databases, and point-of-sale systems.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.2 User Interfaces: RMS allows staff to manage ingredients, dish preparation, and orders.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.3 Hardware Interfaces: RMS supports barcode scanners and tablets for order entry.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.4 Software Interfaces: RMS uses PostgreSQL for structured data, MongoDB for inventory, REST APIs for transactions, and OAuth 2.0 with TLS encryption.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.5 Communications Interfa: RMS secures data via TLS encryption and role-based access control.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.6 Memory Constraints: RMS is optimized for real-time tracking and stock updates.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.7 Operations: RMS manages meals, reservations, and waiter assignments.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.8 Site Adaptation Requir: RMS is configurable for different restaurant sizes.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.9 Interfaces with Servic: RMS connects with food suppliers, reservations, billing services, Google Cloud Storage, and Google Analytics.

[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.5 User Characteristics: RMS is designed for managers, waiters, and chefs.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.7 Assumptions and Dependencie: RMS relies on updated stock, valid client data, and assigned waiters.
[SUBSEC] 1.8 Definitions: Meal: A collection of served dishes.

[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-001: The system shall manage ingredient stock, including name, quantity, and unit (REQ-DB-001).
[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-002: The system shall track dish composition (REQ-DB-002).

[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-001: The system shall allow dish registration with ingredients (REQ-DB-002).
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-002: The system shall track meals and assigned waiters (REQ-DB-003).
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-003: The system shall record waiter details, including ID and assigned meals (REQ-DB-003).

[SUBSEC] 2.3 Usability Requirements.REQ-USAB-001: The system shall provide an interface for managing ingredients, meals, and assignments.

[SUBSEC] 2.4 Performance Requirements.REQ-PERF-001: The system shall update inventory and meal tracking within 1 second of an order or stock change.

[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-001: The system shall store ingredient details, including name, unit, and quantity.
[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-002: The system shall maintain dish composition records.
[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-003: The system shall store meal details, including table number, ordered dishes, assigned waiters, and timestamps.

[SUBSEC] 2.6 Design Constraints.REQ-DSGN-001: The system shall enforce unique identification for ingredients, dishes, and waiters.

[SUBSEC] 2.7 Standards Compliance.REQ-COMP-001: The system shall comply with food safety standards.

[SUBSEC] 2.8 Software System Attributes.REQ-ATTR-001: The system shall log ingredient updates and meal records.

[SEC] 3. Verification: Tests meal tracking, dish creation, and assignments.
[SEC] 4. Supporting Information: User manuals, API documentation, and restaurant policies.
[SEC] 5. References: Food service guidelines, customer tracking, and inventory management.
